Tabulating data

Richard Layton

2021-06-30

Source: vignettes/art-060-tabulating-data.Rmd
art-060-tabulating-data.Rmd

Introduction

Outline

  • Practice tabulating multiway data

This vignette uses

midfieldr functions

  • condition_multiway()

packages

# packages used
library("midfieldr")
library("midfielddata")

library("ggplot2")
library("janitor")
library("data.table")

We can control how a data.table is printed to the screen with the following options.

# optional code to control data.table printing
options(
  datatable.print.nrows = 10,
  datatable.print.topn = 5,
  datatable.print.class = TRUE
)

Tabulating data

Data tables are useful in discussions with one’s research team and are often included in publications for readers who want to see the values underlying the data graphics.

Our example data are currently laid out in “block record” form [1], where the race_sex key and the program key are both in columns and the response, stickiness, is in the last column. This layout is also called “tidy data” [2].

The graphing package we use, ggplot2, is designed to work most effectively with block-record data, thus the block-record (“long”) form is the default layout in midfieldr.

Table 1: Stickiness (block records)
program race_sex stick med_program med_race_sex
Civil Asian Female 70.6 58.90 70.85
Civil Black Female 51.9 58.90 56.95
Civil White Female 70.5 58.90 65.10
Civil Asian Male 64.9 58.90 63.90
Civil Black Male 43.9 58.90 45.90
Civil Hispanic/Latinx Male 58.9 58.90 60.35
Civil International Male 42.9 58.90 52.95
Civil Other/Unknown Male 31.2 58.90 50.00
Civil White Male 68.3 58.90 65.10
Electrical Asian Female 71.1 62.45 70.85
Electrical Black Female 61.7 62.45 56.95
Electrical Hispanic/Latinx Female 71.4 62.45 72.05
Electrical White Female 63.2 62.45 65.10
Electrical Asian Male 64.5 62.45 63.90
Electrical Black Male 45.1 62.45 45.90
Electrical Hispanic/Latinx Male 55.2 62.45 60.35
Electrical International Male 59.2 62.45 52.95
Electrical Other/Unknown Male 50.0 62.45 50.00
Electrical White Male 63.7 62.45 65.10
Industrial Asian Female 50.0 59.60 70.85
Industrial Black Female 58.5 59.60 56.95
Industrial White Female 60.7 59.60 65.10
Industrial Asian Male 63.3 59.60 63.90
Industrial Black Male 53.8 59.60 45.90
Industrial Hispanic/Latinx Male 88.0 59.60 60.35
Industrial International Male 54.5 59.60 52.95
Industrial White Male 65.0 59.60 65.10
Mechanical Asian Female 82.6 61.80 70.85
Mechanical Black Female 55.4 61.80 56.95
Mechanical Hispanic/Latinx Female 72.7 61.80 72.05
Mechanical White Female 67.0 61.80 65.10
Mechanical Asian Male 63.1 61.80 63.90
Mechanical Black Male 46.7 61.80 45.90
Mechanical Hispanic/Latinx Male 61.8 61.80 60.35
Mechanical International Male 51.4 61.80 52.95
Mechanical Native American Male 57.1 61.80 57.10
Mechanical Other/Unknown Male 58.3 61.80 50.00
Mechanical White Male 65.2 61.80 65.10


However, the visual convention preferred by publishers and readers is a row-record (“wide”) form, as illustrated by Table 2. The race_sex key is in the left column and the program key is in the column names. The stickiness findings lie at the row-column intersections. Note that in this form, the four NA observations we mentioned earlier are explicitly shown.

Table 2: Stickiness (row records)
race_sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical
Asian Female 70.6 71.1 50.0 82.6
Asian Male 64.9 64.5 63.3 63.1
Black Female 51.9 61.7 58.5 55.4
Black Male 43.9 45.1 53.8 46.7
Hispanic/Latinx Female NA 71.4 NA 72.7
Hispanic/Latinx Male 58.9 55.2 88.0 61.8
International Male 42.9 59.2 54.5 51.4
Native American Male NA NA NA 57.1
Other/Unknown Male 31.2 50.0 NA 58.3
White Female 70.5 63.2 60.7 67.0
White Male 68.3 63.7 65.0 65.2

Depending on your software background, you may have encountered a block-record/row-record transformation using any of these function pairs—a list adapted from [1].

  • pivot / anti-pivot or crosstab / shred (databases)
  • pivot_to_rowrecs / unpivot_to_blocks (cdata)
  • reshape “wide” / reshape “long” (R)
  • pivot_wider / pivot_longer (tidyr)
  • pivot / unpivot (Microsoft Excel)
  • dcast / melt (data.table)
  • cast / melt (reshape2)

In our example, we use dcast() from the data.table package to reshape the data for publication. We start by limiting the significant figures of floating-point numbers.

# create a new memory location
block_form <- copy(DT)

# limit significant digits
block_form[, stick := round(stick, 2)]

If in the final result we want rows and columns ordered alphabetically, we convert factors to characters.

# create a new memory location
row_form <- copy(block_form)

# convert factors to characters
row_form[, race_sex := as.character(race_sex)]
row_form[, program := as.character(program)]

dcast() is used to reshape the data frame from block-record form to row-record form.

# reshape
row_form <- dcast(row_form, race_sex ~ program, value.var = "stick")

# examine the result
row_form
#>                   race_sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical
#>                     <char> <num>      <num>      <num>      <num>
#>  1:           Asian Female  70.6       71.1       50.0       82.6
#>  2:             Asian Male  64.9       64.5       63.3       63.1
#>  3:           Black Female  51.9       61.7       58.5       55.4
#>  4:             Black Male  43.9       45.1       53.8       46.7
#>  5: Hispanic/Latinx Female    NA       71.4         NA       72.7
#>  6:   Hispanic/Latinx Male  58.9       55.2       88.0       61.8
#>  7:     International Male  42.9       59.2       54.5       51.4
#>  8:   Native American Male    NA         NA         NA       57.1
#>  9:     Other/Unknown Male  31.2       50.0         NA       58.3
#> 10:           White Female  70.5       63.2       60.7       67.0
#> 11:             White Male  68.3       63.7       65.0       65.2

This result is the source for Table 2, repeated below.

Table 2: Stickiness (row records)
race_sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical

Black Female 51.9 61.7 58.5 55.4

White Female 70.5 63.2 60.7 67.0
White Male 68.3 63.7 65.0 65.2

Other good tools for reshaping are provided in packages such as reshape() in base R, cdata [3], and tidyr [4].

Exercise

  1. Create a table of study_grad_rate data similar to the table above.

Tables with totals

When data have not been summarized, as in the study_student data set for example,

study_student
#>              mcid   institution   cip6    program          race    sex
#>            <char>        <char> <char>     <char>        <char> <char>
#>    1: MID25783197 Institution M 140801      Civil         White   Male
#>    2: MID25783441 Institution M 140801      Civil         White   Male
#>    3: MID25783553 Institution M 140801      Civil         White   Male
#>    4: MID25784209 Institution M 140801      Civil International   Male
#>    5: MID25784489 Institution M 140801      Civil         Asian Female
#>   ---                                                                 
#> 8215: MID26692926 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White   Male
#> 8216: MID26693368 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White   Male
#> 8217: MID26695626 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White   Male
#> 8218: MID26696116 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White Female
#> 8219: MID26696429 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White Female
#>       timely_term data_sufficiency
#>            <char>           <lgcl>
#>    1:       19923             TRUE
#>    2:       19973             TRUE
#>    3:       20073             TRUE
#>    4:       20003             TRUE
#>    5:       19943             TRUE
#>   ---                             
#> 8215:       20153             TRUE
#> 8216:       20143             TRUE
#> 8217:       20143             TRUE
#> 8218:       20153             TRUE
#> 8219:       20153             TRUE

and what we want is a count of students by group, the result is a frequency table. The janitor package has convenient functions for creating frequency tables and adding row and column totals.

# To access the tabyl() and adorn_total() functions 
library("janitor")

# Create a new memory location 
DT <- copy(study_student)

We join the race/ethnicity and sex variables to construct our usual categories,

# Merge the groups as usual 
DT[, race_sex := paste(race, sex)]

# Examine the result
DT
#>              mcid   institution   cip6    program          race    sex
#>            <char>        <char> <char>     <char>        <char> <char>
#>    1: MID25783197 Institution M 140801      Civil         White   Male
#>    2: MID25783441 Institution M 140801      Civil         White   Male
#>    3: MID25783553 Institution M 140801      Civil         White   Male
#>    4: MID25784209 Institution M 140801      Civil International   Male
#>    5: MID25784489 Institution M 140801      Civil         Asian Female
#>   ---                                                                 
#> 8215: MID26692926 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White   Male
#> 8216: MID26693368 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White   Male
#> 8217: MID26695626 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White   Male
#> 8218: MID26696116 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White Female
#> 8219: MID26696429 Institution L 143501 Industrial         White Female
#>       timely_term data_sufficiency           race_sex
#>            <char>           <lgcl>             <char>
#>    1:       19923             TRUE         White Male
#>    2:       19973             TRUE         White Male
#>    3:       20073             TRUE         White Male
#>    4:       20003             TRUE International Male
#>    5:       19943             TRUE       Asian Female
#>   ---                                                
#> 8215:       20153             TRUE         White Male
#> 8216:       20143             TRUE         White Male
#> 8217:       20143             TRUE         White Male
#> 8218:       20153             TRUE       White Female
#> 8219:       20153             TRUE       White Female

Use tabyl() to create the two-way frequency table of counts,

# Create the two-way frequency table
DT <- tabyl(DT, race_sex, program)

# Examine the result
DT
#>                race_sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical
#>            Asian Female    17         38         40         23
#>              Asian Male    37        197         60        122
#>            Black Female    54        154         94         83
#>              Black Male    98        304        106        214
#>  Hispanic/Latinx Female    10         14          6         11
#>    Hispanic/Latinx Male    56         67         25         76
#>    International Female     1          8          5          3
#>      International Male    14         71         22         37
#>  Native American Female     0          3          1          5
#>    Native American Male     7          8          1         14
#>    Other/Unknown Female     6          8          3          8
#>      Other/Unknown Male    16         28          2         48
#>            White Female   329        193        234        291
#>              White Male  1147       1366        494       1940

Use adorn_totals() to add row totals, column totals, or (as shown here) both,

# Add row and column totals 
DT <- adorn_totals(DT, where = c("row", "col"))

# Examine the result
DT
#>                race_sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical Total
#>            Asian Female    17         38         40         23   118
#>              Asian Male    37        197         60        122   416
#>            Black Female    54        154         94         83   385
#>              Black Male    98        304        106        214   722
#>  Hispanic/Latinx Female    10         14          6         11    41
#>    Hispanic/Latinx Male    56         67         25         76   224
#>    International Female     1          8          5          3    17
#>      International Male    14         71         22         37   144
#>  Native American Female     0          3          1          5     9
#>    Native American Male     7          8          1         14    30
#>    Other/Unknown Female     6          8          3          8    25
#>      Other/Unknown Male    16         28          2         48    94
#>            White Female   329        193        234        291  1047
#>              White Male  1147       1366        494       1940  4947
#>                   Total  1792       2459       1093       2875  8219

References

[1]
J. Mount and N. Zumel, “Coordinatized data: A fluid data specification.” Win Vector LLC, 2019 [Online]. Available: http://winvector.github.io/FluidData/RowsAndColumns.html
[2]
H. Wickham and G. Grolemund, R for Data Science. Sebastopol, CA: O’Reilly Media, Inc., 2017 [Online]. Available: https://r4ds.had.co.nz/
[3]
J. Mount and N. Zumel, cdata: Fluid Data Transformations. R package version 1.1.6, 2020 [Online]. Available: https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=cdata
[4]
H. Wickham and L. Henry, tidyr: Tidy Messy Data. R package version 1.1.0, 2020 [Online]. Available: https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tidyr

Appendix

Complete script

The vignette code chunks are collected below in a single, condensed script.

# packages used
library("midfieldr")
library("data.table")
library("ggplot2")

# optional code to control data.table printing
options(
  datatable.print.nrows = 10,
  datatable.print.topn = 5,
  datatable.print.class = TRUE
)
